Week 14 college football recap

TOT’s Victor Kevorkian breaks down a wild championship weekend which made for perhaps the most controversial selection day in the history of the four-team playoff.

Alabama quarterback Jalen Milroe holds up the SEC Championship MVP trophy.  (AP/Mike Stewart)

By Victor Kevorkian
December 05, 2023 at  5:57 pm PST

Alabama tops Georgia to win SEC Championship, 27-24
The Bulldogs came into this one winners of 29 straight, but Nick Saban’s squad prevailed against his former assistant’s powerhouse. Alabama quarterback Jalen Milroe was precise in the biggest game of his collegiate career, making plays with his legs when needed and finding his receivers throughout. Milroe completed 13 of his 23 pass attempts for 192 yards and two touchdowns, adding 29 yards on the ground. Milroe’s performance saw him winning the MVP of the game.

Running back Roydell Williams led the team in rushing with 64 yards and a score, while receiver Isiah Bond led the way with 79 receiving yards. Alabama jumped out to an early 17-7 lead, but Georgia did not roll over. The Bulldogs clawed their way back, cutting the lead to one possession multiple times throughout the second half. However, Milroe and the offense did a great job of sustaining long, methodical drives ending in scores, keeping Georgia off the field and holding on to win the SEC.

Georgia quarterback Carson Beck commanded a solid offensive effort, completing 21 of his 29 pass attempts for 243 yards. Beck found the endzone on a quarterback sneak early in the fourth but also lost a fumble. Running back Kendall Milton led the ground attack with 42 yards and two touchdowns, while tight end Brock Bowers caught five balls for 53 yards. The Bulldogs were in this one throughout, and Beck’s fumble on a miscued handoff could be looked back at as the turning point.

Alabama (12-1) wins the SEC and punches its ticket to the college football playoff. The Tide finish at No. 4 in the rankings and will face Michigan in the semifinal. Their big win against the back-to-back champions boded well in the committee’s decision despite their early loss to Texas. Georgia (12-1) drops five spots to No. 6 in the rankings. In what seemed like another potential championship run for the Bulldogs, they seemed to catch Alabama at the wrong time. Georgia is set to face Florida State in the Orange Bowl.

Washington escapes with win vs. Oregon in Pac-12 Championship, 34-31
The final Pac-12 Championship did not disappoint, as two conference powerhouses rematched for a potential spot in the playoff. The second matchup between these teams gave a sense of deja vu, as the Huskies prevailed by three points once again.

Washington got major contributions from a multitude of positions, starting from its signal caller. Quarterback Michael Penix completed 27 of his 39 pass attempts for 319 yards, one touchdown and one interception. While Penix’s stats aren’t necessarily jaw-dropping, the Heisman candidate continuously made tight window throws to keep the Huskies offense moving, granting him the game’s MVP award.

Penix’s favorite target on the day was receiver Jalen McMillan, who caught nine balls for 131 yards. Washington’s best pass catcher Rome Odunze also eclipsed 100 yards, as the Huskies passing attack seemed unstoppable. Star running back Dillon Johnson also got in on the action, carrying the ball 28 times for 152 yards and two touchdowns.

Penix and the offense were able to run the clock down late in the game, preventing any chance at an Oregon comeback. The Ducks also had an efficient offensive performance. Fellow Heisman candidate Bo Nix added to his impressive statistical season, throwing for 239 yards, three touchdowns and one interception. Nix also led the team in rushing with 69 on six attempts, while Tez Johnson led the team with 68 receiving yards.

While Nix had a nice day and the Ducks were able to keep things close throughout, the difference in this one was time of possession and third-down efficiency. Washington out-possessed Oregon 37:08-22:52 and converted on 66% of their third downs compared to the Ducks’ 30%.

Washington (13-0) finishes at No. 2 in the CFP rankings and will face Texas in the semifinal. A truly dominant season for the Huskies in the last year of the Pac-12 made for their first playoff appearance since 2016. Oregon (11-2) dropped to No. 8 in the rankings. An elite roster made for one of the most exhilarating teams in college football. But it seemed the Huskies had their number all year, handing them both of their losses. Oregon is set to face Liberty in the Fiesta Bowl.

Florida State takes ACC crown in slugfest vs. Louisville, 16-6
An unfortunate stretch of injuries at the quarterback position made for a rocky end to the season for Florida State. The Seminoles were forced to turn to true freshman Brock Glenn in relief of Tate Rodemaker who suffered a concussion last week vs Florida. Glenn was put in a tough spot for his first true action at the collegiate level and struggled to get things going.

He completed eight of his 21 pass attempts for 55 yards, finding just three receivers on the day. The Seminoles’ inability to throw the ball effectively forced them to turn to their ground attack, where they found success. Running back Lawrance Toafili ran for 118 yards and one touchdown on 18 carries.

Toafili was one of the only positives for the Seminole offense, resulting in him being awarded the game’s MVP. Although the Seminoles failed to get the ball rolling, the Cardinals were even worse. Quarterback Jake Plummer completed 14 of his 36 pass attempts for 111 yards and an interception.

Running back Jawhar Jordan led the team with 52 rushing yards while receiver Jamari Thrash led all receivers with 57 yards. A sluggish day on offense saw the Cardinals fail to find the endzone. It was Florida State’s defense that propelled them to this victory.

The unit put up impressive numbers across the board. They allowed just 188 total yards, 10 first downs, and sacked Plummer seven times. The Cardinals went a combined 3 of 21 on third and fourth downs.

Despite the win, Florida State (13-0) dropped to No. 5 in the rankings and became the first undefeated Power Five champion to miss the playoff, an unfortunate end to the season, as the Seminoles were essentially a playoff lock had Jordan Travis remained healthy. The committee clearly took note of the offense’s dip in production throughout the past couple of weeks and simply felt they were not a top-four team anymore.

The ‘Noles are set to face Georgia in the Orange Bowl. As for Louisville (10-3), they finish at No. 15 in the rankings and will face USC in the holiday bowl.

Michigan routs Iowa in Big Ten Championship, 26-0
The Wolverines showed why they are deserving of the country’s top spot in Jim Harbaugh’s return to the sideline. Michigan’s offense did not have its greatest performance of the season, but did what was needed to escape Indianapolis with the Big Ten title.

Quarterback J.J. McCarthy had an efficient showing in a game where not much was asked, completing 73% of his passes for 147 yards. McCarthy’s top target was receiver Cornelius Johnson, who hauled in nine catches for 64 yards.

Running back Blake Corum was the Wolverines’ most efficient playmaker, carrying the ball 16 times for 52 yards and two touchdowns. As for Iowa, this game saw its offense converting for just seven first downs and totaling 155 yards.

Quarterback Deacon Hill completed 18 of his 32 pass attempts for 120 yards. His top target was Addison Ostrenga, who hauled in seven balls for 50 yards. The Hawkeyes’ top rusher was Leshon Williams who rushed for just 25 yards.

Iowa’s inability to run the ball led to seven punts and just 23 minutes of possession. Michigan’s defensive efforts were led by Mike Sainristil, a receiver turned defensive back. Sainristil forced two fumbles and was flying all over the field to make tackles.

He was awarded the game’s MVP. Michigan (13-0) finishes the 2023 season atop the college football world at No. 1 in the rankings. They will face a hot Alabama team in the semifinal. Iowa slides to No. 17 in the rankings and will face Tennessee in the Citrus Bowl.

Texas takes care of Oklahoma State to win Big 12, 49-21
Texas captured its fourth Big 12 title and its first since 2009 in the program’s last year as part of the conference. Longhorns quarterback Quinn Ewers saved his best performance of the season for the championship bout.

Ewers completed 35 of his 46 pass attempts for 452 yards, four touchdowns and one interception. Texas had two receivers hit the 100-yard mark in this one. Adonai Mitchell led the team, catching six balls for 109 yards and one touchdown.

Tight end Ja’Tavion Sanders followed suit, hauling in eight of his nine targets for 105 yards and a score. The Longhorns were able to establish a ground attack as well, rushing for 198 yards on the day.

Running back Keilan Robinson led the way with 75 of those yards and two touchdowns. Oklahoma State’s offense failed to stay on the field, ending the game with under 20 minutes of possession.

That being said, Cowboys quarterback Alan Bowman put together a solid statistical performance. He threw for 250 yards, three touchdowns and one interception. Bowman’s favorite target on the day was Brennan Presley, who hauled in nine balls for 93 yards and one touchdown.

Perhaps the most disappointing aspect of Oklahoma State’s offense was the inability to get Ollie Gordon going. Gordon is one of the most dynamic backs in the country, but was unable to make an impact on the ground. He rushed 13 times for just 34 yards, albeit he did find some success in the passing game with 54 yards through the air.

Texas (12-1) find themselves ranked No. 3 in the final rankings. Although a one-loss team, the committee felt the Longhorns had an impressive enough resume throughout the season to net them a spot in the playoff over undefeated Florida State.

The Longhorns are set to face Washington in the semifinal. Oklahoma State finishes at No. 20 in the rankings, and will face Texas A&M in the TaxAct Bowl.

Liberty beats New Mexico State in Conference USA Championship, 49-35
With the game knotted up at 35 apiece heading into the final frame, a 14-0 fourth quarter from the unbeaten Flames propelled them to a win over the Aggies in their inaugural season as members of the C-USA.

Liberty quarterback Kaidon Salter continued his efficient 2023 campaign with a great showing. He completed 20 of his 25 pass attempts for 319 yards and two touchdowns. Salter was not done there.

He led the team in rushing with 165 yards, a season high, while adding another score on the ground. Receiver CJ Daniels led the team in receiving, tying his season high in yards with 157 and one touchdown.

As for the Aggies, they saw two quarterbacks in action on Friday. Diego Pavia started the game under center and was putting together a very solid performance. He completed 11 of his 16 pass attempts for 188 yards and three touchdowns.

He also added 45 yards and a touchdown on the ground, leading the team in rushing. Pavia was forced out of action in the third quarter after apparently reaggravating an elbow injury.

Backup Blaze Berlowitz entered the game in relief of Pavia, and although he put up a solid statistical performance, there was a clear dropoff in NMSU’s offensive pace. Berlowitz completed 10 of his 19 pass attempts for 134 yards, one touchdown and one interception.

Trent Hudson was the Aggies’ leading receiver with seven catches for 112 yards and two touchdowns. Liberty (13-0) finishes the year ranked No. 23, and is set to face Oregon in the Fiesta Bowl.

Unranked New Mexico State (10-4) will face Fresno State in the Isleta New Mexico Bowl.

SMU upsets Tulane in AAC Championship, 26-14
SMU cracked the College Football Playoff Top 25 rankings for the first time this season with an assertive second half in the American Athletic Conference championship game.

Mustang quarterback Kevin Jennings made his first career collegiate start in this one, putting up subpar numbers in the win. He completed 19 of his 33 pass attempts for 203 yards, one touchdown and two interceptions.

Jennings added 63 yards rushing to his day. SMU’s leading rusher was running back Jaylan Knighton, who carried the ball 15 times for 75 yards and one touchdown. Tight end RJ Maryland led the team with 56 receiving yards.

An opening play strip sack placed the ball on the 1-yard-line for the Green Wave offense, who quickly took a 7-0 lead. The offense would struggle from then on out, scoring just 7 more points in the next 59 minutes.

Quarterback Michael Pratt didn’t have the day he was hoping for, throwing for 238 yards, one touchdown and one interception. Pratt was sacked seven times and the offense was forced to punt nine times on the day, totaling only 12 first downs.

Tulane struggled to get anything going on the ground, rushing for just 31 yards. The only bright spot on the Green Wave offense was receiver Yulkeith Brown, who caught five balls for 90 yards and a score.

SMU (11-2) entered the rankings this week at No. 24. They are set to play Boston College in the Fenway Bowl. Tulane (11-2) exits the CFP rankings for the first time this season. The Green Wave will take on Virginia Tech in the Military Bowl.

D’Anton Lynn excited for new start at USC

The Trojans’ new defensive coordinator addressed the media for the first time about his plans for the future of USC football.

UCLA defensive coordinator D'Anton Lynn talks with linebacker Choe Bryant-Strother (9) during a timeout during the second half of an NCAA college football game against Southern California in Los Angeles, Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. (AP Photo/Ashley Landis)

By Terence Holton December 05, 2023 at  2:33 pm PST

There’s a new sheriff in town for the USC defensive staff, and his name is D’Anton Lynn. Formerly the defensive coordinator at UCLA under Chip Kelly, Lynn led UCLA to one of the top defenses in the country, including the No. 2 rush defense, No. 11 total defense and No. 3 in tackles for loss.

In his first media availability since being hired by USC last week, Lynn discussed his plans for the future with this USC team, and how he’s excited for a fresh start across town. Lynn’s schemes were a popular conversation point throughout the press conference, and he made it clear that it is about the team.

“From a schematic standpoint, my thing is, it’s all about the players to put them in the best position to play fast and make plays.” Lynn said. “Really excited to get this next recruiting class in to see what this teams going to look like next spring and what is the best way to put this USC team in the best position to win.”

One of the largest problems which has plagued the Trojans for quite some time is tackling. Lynn was keen to highlight the importance of bringing down the opponents.

“Tackling is always the thing you have to emphasize. I’m a big believer in [that] you have to emphasize fundamentals over and over again, and at all positions,” he said. “It’s something that you have to do all throughout the year, whether it’s drills or showing guys good examples and bad examples on tape, it’s just something that has to be emphasized.”

Lynn outlined that when looking for those guys to make those stops at all levels of the defense, he is looking for adaptable and all-around players — someone who can do more than one thing.

“The biggest thing across all positions is versatility. It’s hard in the way the game is played now in college and the NFL to just do one thing,” Lynn said. “You want versatile guys up front who can align in different spots. From a linebacker and secondary standpoint, same thing — versatility and football instincts, guys who are very passionate and love football.”

One of the biggest questions about Lynn as defensive coordinator is who he will keep on from the defensive staff. Lynn told the media he has yet to meet much of the staff; he has been on the recruiting trail the past couple days.

While it is unclear which coaches will stay and which will go, Lynn has a very clear goal in mind for this Trojan team.

“I want to play the best defense possible. I think that we have every reason to, and one of the reasons I was so excited about this job is because I felt that, after my conversations with Coach Riley and Jennifer Cohen, they are passionate about playing really elite defense here at SC by any means necessary.”

With the Trojans departing for the Big Ten in 2024, many questions are circling about whether USC will be able to handle the rough-and-tumble style the midwestern teams play with. Lynn is well aware and knows he has to put this defense in the best position to win.

“We’re going to see different styles in the Big Ten, and that’s something where we have to do a good job in the spring, making sure we’re seeing the stuff we’re going to see in the fall,” Lynn said. “We have to make sure that we’re preparing our guys all throughout the spring, that way in Week 3 against Michigan, we’re not showing them this for the very first time.”

The Alex Grinch defense era is over, and D’Anton Lynn has been handed all the keys to the defensive kingdom. While he has all of the offseason to prepare, Lynn’s new philosophies and schemes may need to take shape quickly as in 2024, the Trojans take on LSU, Michigan, Penn State, Washington and Notre Dame, all strong opponents.

Lynn won’t coach USC in its upcoming Holiday Bowl game against No. 15 Louisville; however, he will likely be watching, analyzing what needs to change on the defensive side.

Lincoln Riley talks about the future of USC football

USC head coach Lincoln Riley discussed the near and far future of his program during media availability Monday morning. (Photo by Carly Rieger)

By Lily Coleman December 04, 2023 at 7:43 pm PST

USC football head coach Lincoln Riley held a Zoom press conference on Monday to discuss staff changes, the Trojans’ upcoming bowl game and the team’s future development. After a disappointing 2023 football season, USC football looks ahead to the future with a new defensive coordinator and a bowl game against Louisville. However, Riley announced that junior quarterback and reigning Heisman trophy winner Caleb Williams will not play in the postseason matchup.

On December 1, USC announced the hiring of D’Anton Lynn as the team’s new defensive coordinator following the firing of Alex Grinch. Lynn had the same role at UCLA this past season and previously spent nine seasons coaching in the NFL. “[Lynn] stood out to me from the first conversation that we had and just his vision for, obviously the job he’d done at UCLA, but for what this could be here,” Riley said. “You’re looking for people that are going to come in and make us better ... but also people that have a shared vision of USC, what this program means, what it can be and what it needs to continue to climb. I think he’s a rising star in this coaching profession.”

Riley explained that there will be a lot of philosophical changes implemented as the USC coaching staff works to rebuild the Trojan defense. “I think from a philosophical standpoint, we’re going to teach [and] we’re going to develop in a different way to make sure that we fit exactly what we want to be defensively,” Riley said. “Everything here is going to be done with the defensive line first.” Riley has high hopes for the future of USC’s defense. “Something that we’re staying focused on is building the best defensive staff in America here,” he said. “Whether it’s somebody here or somebody outside the program, that’s what we’re going to do, that’s what we’re going to build.”

Additionally, the college transfer portal opened today, and Riley shared what that means for his team. “We’re certainly going to be targeting a couple of positions in the portal. I think it’s going to continue to taper down, and that has kind of been our goal from the beginning,” he said of the program’s strategy in utilizing the portal. Riley talked about his goals for developing the program as a whole, beginning two years ago with establishing team culture and a roster with championship potential. He explained that, overall, the team is focusing on signing high school players, continuing to develop current players, and supplementing with players from the transfer portal.

Riley also expressed his excitement for the upcoming DIRECTV Holiday Bowl that will take place at Petco Park in San Diego on December 27. “I think it’s important for us that we’re getting to be able to play the game here in our home state, [and] playing the game in an area that historically has meant very much to USC football,” Riley said. Historically, USC has acquired some of its top players from San Diego, including names such as Heisman-winning tailback Marcus Allen, running back Reggie Bush, and linebacker Junior Seau. “It’s an opportunity that we need to recognize and we need to be ready to take advantage of,” Riley said.

Despite having two bye weeks this season, this will be the longest gap between games for USC — the Trojans last played on November 18. Riley discussed the advantage of having an increased number of practices, which will be beneficial for not only the upcoming game, but also for the continued development of players for next season. “We’ll have a handful of guys that don’t play in this game, and the excitement for us is now that this game doesn’t count in the redshirt rules for some of these players, it’s going to be an opportunity in a lot of ways for these guys to really step up,” Riley said. “You almost feel like, in a way, it’s kind of halfway to the last game of this year and kind of halfway to the first game of next year in some ways, and a tremendous opportunity for these young guys.”

Putting the bowl game aside, Riley discussed what will go into looking for potential new quarterbacks as Caleb Williams has yet to announce whether he will stay at USC or go to the NFL draft. “We’re going to look in the [transfer] portal at some quarterbacks, we’ll see how that thing unfolds,” he said. “I like the guys that we have in the room, but also, you always have a responsibility to the team to continue to look at potential people that can come in and make our room better and make our team better. I’m not ready to say that we would for sure do anything, we’re just going to take a look and evaluate, and see how it all unfolds.”

Lynn will address the USC media for the first time on Tuesday at noon in a Zoom press conference. Annenberg Media will have a story to follow.

The best albums of 2023

From Taylor Swift to Bad Bunny, to indie pop to rap, here is a wrap-up of our top albums of the year

From SZA's "SOS," to Daniel Caesar's "Never Enough," 2023 has been a stellar year for new album releases.

By Eda Katgi and Thuanh Su
December 04, 2023 at 11:22 am PST

Discover the albums that shaped 2023 and are a must-listen. From Olivia Rodrigo’s irresistible sophomore album “GUTS” which left fans eager for more, to Taylor’s Version of “1989′′ which claimed the No. 1 spot on the Billboard Top 200, as well as Grammy-nominated for Best New Artist, Gracie Abrams’ with her album “Good Riddance.”

SZA’s “SOS”
SZA’s “SOS” album which was released in December 2022 was too late for roundups for “Best Albums of 2023′′ but this album deserves its moment. After a five-year break, SZA dropped one of the most popular albums of 2023. The album was the third most listened album of 2023 and made No. 1 on top R&B/Hip-Hop albums. Taking the lead for most nominations for the Grammy awards, 2024 will be her year.

Gracie Abrams’s “Good Riddance”
Coming off her solo tour and opening up for Taylor Swift, Abrams has had a successful year. In her album “Good Riddance,” emotional transparency takes over as she intricately laces her thoughts into a melodic narrative. It stands as a testament to the power of raw emotion and resonates with fans. The popular songs “ I know it won’t work ” and “ Amelie ” are emotional ballads that hold the singer’s inner thoughts.

Daniel Caesar’s “Never Enough”
“Never Enough,” is the R&B singer-songwriter’s third album and it proves that Caesar is a genius when it comes to lyrics of love and heartbreak. After major success with his songs “ Best Part ” featuring H.E.R. and “ Get You ” featuring Kali Uchis, Caesar has done it again with his songs  “Always”  and  “Let Me Go”  on the album. Each track delivers emotional ballads that create an intimate bond with the listener.

Jonas Brothers’ “The Album”
From their Las Vegas residency to an international tour, the Jonas Brothers released their seventh album “The Album.” The tracks from the album include whimsical, soothing and uplifting melodies. Some hit songs you may know are “ Wings ,” “ Waffle House ” and  “Vacation Eyes.”  Currently, they are on an international tour singing not just one album but five of their most popular albums. Fans have been obsessing over Joe Jonas’ solo performance to “ Vacation Eyes , " a popular song on “The Album.”

Drake’s “For All the Dogs”
Some of you may know him as Drizzy or Champagne Papi but Drake released his long-awaited album “For All The Dogs” back in October and  fans loved it . Released while finishing up his “It’s All A Blur Tour” with 21 Savage, Drake’s album features a star-studded lineup of collaborators. From J. Cole to Lil Yachty, the beats to the album are great for a girls’ night out. In an  album review , Drake had the best ten collaborators that added their own twist to each track.

Olivia Rodrigo’s “GUTS”
Want him back? More like  “get him back.”  The track is one of the most popular songs on Rodrigo’s sophomore album “GUTS.” The album gained popularity as fans created their own  TikTok  dancing trends to multiple songs off the highly-anticipated album. “GUTS” was filled with various music genres such as pop-punk, emo, and alt-rock. Songs like  “all-american bitch”  and  “ballad of a homeschooled girl”  had lyrics that explained what it feels like to be a girl who lives in America with social anxiety. At her one-night-only concert in LA, Rodrigo mentioned that she took a  poetry class at USC  which helped her write “lacy.”

Jack Harlow’s “Jackman.”
“ Lovin On Me ” and “Lovin” on Jack Harlow. Some may have not liked Harlow’s album “Jackman,” but this album showed the authenticity of who Jack Harlow is. Unlike most artists who write music, Harlow put out an album that spoke from his heart, his past and his childhood. It was personable and explained who he (Jackman) really is.

Sabrina Carpenter’s “emails i can’t send”
After releasing her album “emails i can’t send” in July 2022, Carpenter decided to re-release it with the new title “emails i can’t send fwd:” in March 2023. The album came after a long pause for the singer but showed a more vulnerable side to her as it gave fans an inside scoop into her personal life. With major hits,  “Feather,”  and  “Nonsense,”  the world fell in love with Carpenter’s witty lyrics. Carpenter is currently on tour opening up for Taylor Swift and is known to adjust the ending of her popular song  “Nonsense”  to fit the city she is in. Carpenter also recently released her own Christmas album “Fruitcake” which features a  holiday version of “Nonsense,”  which has become the “it” jingle of the season.

Bad Bunny’s “nadie sabe lo que va a pasar mañana”
With his fifth solo album, Puerto Rican musician Bad Bunny released “nadie sabe lo que va a pasar mañana” this year. This album was highly anticipated by many worldwide and pays tribute to the singer’s early days of Latin trap music. With popular songs  “PERRO NEGRO”  and  “WHERE SHE GOES,”  Bad Bunny’s voice and addictive beats will even capture the ears of non-Spanish speakers. The song  “MONACO”  has taken the world by storm with its captivating intro and has been a popular sound being used by  TikTok  users all over the world.

Taylor Swift’s “1989 (Taylor’s Version)”
After re-recording most of her albums, the singer known as  “mother”  to many of her fans has been listed as the most-streamed artist globally in 2023 according to  Spotify Wrapped.  Her re-recordings of popular songs of  “Style”  and  “Wildest Dreams”  can be heard almost everywhere. Taking the runner-up with six Grammy nominations, Taylor Swift continues to put out music that is loved by nearly everybody and is currently on her international tour.

No. 6 USC women’s basketball trounces San Diego, remains undefeated

The three-headed monster of Watkins, Marshall and Forbes put the Trojans on top.

For the third straight game, freshman guard JuJu Watkins had 30 points against San Diego Sunday afternoon. (Photo by Jonathan Martin)

By Kasey Kazliner
December 03, 2023 at 8:37 pm PST

No. 6 USC women’s basketball kept its perfect streak alive following a 89-58 routing of San Diego Sunday afternoon at Galen Center. The Trojans were riding high after a 41-point victory over Cal Poly on Tuesday night and kept the momentum going against the Toreros.

Freshman guard JuJu Watkins, the recipient of all three Pac-12 Freshman of the Week awards thus far, continued to shine with 30 points and eight boards. Graduate guard McKenzie Forbes also made an immediate impact with seven quick points right out of the gate. Forbes went on to tally 12 total points and had five assists.

“I was in the right spots, and I’m encouraged to take those shots when I’m open,” Forbes said. “We’ve been working on pushing the pace, so I just felt like I was really trying to hone in on that, and I think that resulted in a couple of easy buckets.”

Despite Forbes’ early success, the Trojans and Toreros were neck and neck in the first quarter. San Diego’s fast-paced offense responded accordingly when USC would score, which kept the Toreros in the game in the first 10 minutes. At the end of the first quarter, USD only trailed by six.

Watkins’ electric start to the second quarter allowed USC to run away with the game. The Trojans went on a blistering 19-5 run to start the quarter, and Watkins’ ability to score at all three levels gave USC the edge it needed to take a double-digit lead. Her scoring ability was complemented by her elite court vision, which helped her set up teammates for scores.

“There really is not a lot that [Watkins] doesn’t have. I think what we’ve all been the most impressed with is to see her learn and adjust on the fly,” head coach Lindsay Gottlieb said. “Maybe her best gift is that people like playing with her, and she is a teammate that brings a lot of excitement and joy to the team.”

Junior forward Rayah Marshall had a double-double with 20 points — a season high — on top of 12 rebounds. Her defense in the paint was elite, as she was able to record four blocks, too. The Trojan defense, as a whole, flustered the Toreros. San Diego didn’t score in the final 1:42 of the first half.

“Our team is really hungry and eager to win,” Marshall said. “We never underestimated the team and when they came up with that momentum, it was like a moment of reality for us, so we just embraced that and stepped up to the challenge to compete.”

The Trojans’ key to success was scoring in the paint. USC’s whopping 60 points in the key were generated by shiftiness and intelligent playmaking. Redshirt sophomore guard Taylor Bigby’s punishing and-one with 7:18 remaining in the game was indicative of the Trojans’ physicality inside.

Watkins capped off her dominant night with a 3-pointer from the wing to achieve her fifth 30-point game of the season thus far.

“I thought we did a lot of the things we wanted to do,” Gottlieb said. “We’re obviously on a quest to be as good as we can possibly be, so there’s a lot of things we can clean up. But, that was a good day for us.”

USC’s fast-paced offensive attack is showing no signs of slowing down and is constantly dismantling opposing defenses. The Trojans scored 17 points on fast breaks and fed off of the Toreros’ 18 turnovers. And, when USC’s offense couldn’t initially produce points, it used its size to grab offensive boards and rack up second-chance shots. Almost a quarter of the Trojans’ points came off of second opportunities.

The Trojans (7-0) will have a week off before hosting UC Riverside next. The Highlanders will head west to take on USC next Sunday at 3:30 p.m. at Galen Center.

USC football earns Holiday Bowl bid, will face No. 15 Louisville

The Trojans will face the Cardinals for the first time in program history.

Caleb Williams has yet to announce whether he will play in USC's bowl game against Louisville. (Photo by Bryce Dechert)

By Crash "CrashLit" Collier December 03, 2023 at 7:35 pm PST

After losing its regular-season finale in blowout fashion to crosstown rival UCLA, USC football (7-5) looks to end its 2023 campaign with a win over the Louisville Cardinals in the DIRECTV Holiday Bowl on December 27. The Cardinals had a stellar 2023 season, where they finished as the ACC runner-up after losing to No. 5 Florida State 16-6 in the ACC Championship Game and will enter Petco Park with a 10-3 record under first-year head coach Jeff Brohm.

The Cardinals also have the 16th-best defense in the country in yards allowed per game. This will be the first-ever meeting between USC and Louisville.

USC has taken part in the Holiday Bowl three times and has a 1-2 record in the bowl. The Trojans beat Nebraska 45-42 in 2014, lost to Wisconsin in 2015 by a score of 23-21 and lost to Iowa 49-24 in 2019. This will be Louisville’s first time as a Holiday Bowl participant.

The Trojans started the season ranked at No. 6 in the preseason AP Poll and won their first six games of the season. However, they lost five of their final six, the lone win being a 50-49 win over the California Golden Bears in Berkeley on October 28. USC has been unranked since November 5 and has not received votes in either the AP or Coaches polls since November 19.

In addition to falling out of both Pac-12 and national championship contention, USC also fired defensive coordinator Alex Grinch on November 5 following the Trojans’ loss to then-No. 5 Washington, who clinched a spot in the College Football Playoff after defeating Oregon 34-31 in the Pac-12 Championship Game on Friday. As the Huskies and Ducks played in Las Vegas, USC head coach Lincoln Riley introduced D’Anton Lynn as Grinch’s replacement at defensive coordinator.

In addition to questions about the defense, USC also has a lot of players who will likely opt out of the Holiday Bowl in order to avoid injuries and to prepare for the 2024 NFL Draft. Redshirt junior running back MarShawn Lloyd announced earlier on social media that he will declare for the NFL Draft, while senior wide receiver Brendan Rice has accepted an invitation to the Senior Bowl. Junior quarterback Caleb Williams still has yet to decide whether or not he will take advantage of his final year of college eligibility or play in the Holiday Bowl, as he told the LA Times that he will make a “game-time decision” when he is ready. The deadline to declare for the NFL Draft is January 15.

The Trojans look to end their disappointing season on a high note when the Holiday Bowl kicks off on December 27 at 5 p.m. PST on FOX.

Cal narrowly beats out USC to advance to Men’s Water Polo National Championship

Golden Bears score game-winning goal with 1:47 left to clinch it.

After losing to the Golden Bears in the NCAA Tournament, USC has now fallen to Cal three times in men's water polo this season. (Photo by Luis Perez)

By Keely Roy
December 03, 2023 at 4:02 pm PST

Last year, Cal took down the Trojans to clinch the National Championship at the Golden Bears’ home pool. Last night, the Trojans finally had their chance to avenge that loss at Uytengsu Aquatics Center. As expected, emotions were high in the heated rivalry rematch. After a tough fought battle, the USC Trojans fell to the California Golden Bears 10-9 in the Men’s Water Polo NCAA National Semifinals. Cal moves on to the Championship game where they will look for a chance to claim their third straight national title.

The Trojans had matched up against Cal three times this season already before the high-stakes rematch. The Golden Bears had come out on top their first two meetups, but the Trojans edged out the Golden Bears 13-12 in Berkeley to win the MPSF tournament less than two weeks ago. Both teams sailed through the first round of the tournament with their eyes set on this highly anticipated second round matchup. On Friday, No. 2 seeded California blew past Fordham in the first round while hosts, the third-seeded Trojans also advanced with ease in an 18-10 victory over San Jose State in the quarterfinals.

The National Semifinals kicked off on Saturday with No. 1 UCLA taking on No. 4 Princeton at Uytengsu Aquatics Center. The Bruins defeated Princeton 17-13 to secure a spot in the national title game. Then as the sun started to set, fans got ready for the most anticipated game of the day where the Trojans took on the Golden Bears in a heated rivalry match under the lights.

The match was an intense one from beginning to end, as the two teams battled it out in a high-scoring, physical match. The Golden Bears got on the board first, with junior attacker Max Casabella opening the scoring in the first period. Not long after, fellow junior attacker Jake Howerton joined him on the scoresheet. Casabella and Howerton would go on to combine for seven of the Bears’ 10 goals. On the other side of the ball, graduate driver Massimo Di Martire led the Trojans with three goals on the day.

The Trojan defense did a good job shutting down one of Cal’s major offensive threats: reigning NCAA MVP, senior center Nikolaos Papanikolaou, who had racked up 37 goals in only 17 games played heading into the NCAA tournament. Both teams stepped up big on defense, with USC’s redshirt freshman goalkeeper Bernardo Herzer totaling 10 saves and Cal’s senior goalkeeper Adrian Weinberg coming up with 11 saves on the night. The intensity of the game was evident in the 26 total exclusions that kept fans on their toes all game. There was one controversial exclusion called on USC’s sophomore utility Andrej Grgurevic with only 33 seconds left in the game that had Trojan fans particularly outraged.

The Golden Bears led 4-2 at the end of the first period, but the Trojans bounced back in the second period, bringing the score to a one-point differential. It was not until the final minutes of the final period of play that the Golden Bears were able to separate. With under two minutes to go and a National title match berth on the line, the Trojans and Golden Bears were at a stalemate — tied 9-9. Cal regained possession of the ball and it landed in the hands of Cal sophomore attacker Marci Szatmary. Instead of looking to pass the ball to a more senior player closer to goal, he decided to go for it and ended up netting the game winning goal on a deep shot. The last minute of regulation proved to be even more eventful as the Trojans had multiple attempts at an equalizer with time expiring before being added back onto the clock.

The Bears held onto their lead following Szatmary’s late heroics, defeating the Trojans 10-9 to advance to the National Championship title match. Cal will go on to face No. 1 seeded UCLA in the National Championship game today at Uytengsu Aquatics Center at 3 p.m. Tickets can be purchased online or at the gate and the game will also be streamed on ESPNU.

USC men’s basketball suffers worst loss of season against Gonzaga

Coming off of its largest win of the season so far, USC men’s basketball traveled to the Legends of Basketball Las Vegas Invitational to take on No. 11 Gonzaga Saturday night. The Trojans battled early but ultimately let the Bulldogs run away with the game in the second half to win 89-76.

The Trojans put together an explosive offensive performance in their last showing against Eastern Washington, but they struggled to generate points early in Saturday’s matchup. Gonzaga went on a 13-0 run for an early 15-2 lead, and USC seemed stunned. It took almost five minutes of play for the Trojans to score their second bucket of the game; they were 1-of-8 from the floor before that point.

In the middle of the first, USC struggled with shot selection and passing, but eventually began to find their footing. With the Trojans down 26-15, fifth-year guard Boogie Ellis took an offensive foul that provided a shift in momentum towards USC. On the next play, graduate forward DJ Rodman scored on an assist from freshman guard Isaiah Collier. Another stop led to a 3-pointer from junior guard Kobe Johnson on the next possession.

USC scraped its way back into the game, holding Gonzaga scoreless for 3:30. The Trojans kept it close through most of the first half, but a 5-0 Gonzaga run brought the Bulldogs’ lead back to eight with 2:43 left. Collier assisted on back-to-back 3-pointers (one to Ellis, one to Rodman) as USC pulled closer. But, the Trojans struggled with their free throws, shooting only 1-for-8 from the line in the period. Gonzaga led by seven at the half.

USC got off to a slow start in the second half, and Gonzaga opened up a 15-point lead. Collier and Ellis brought the deficit to nine, but Gonzaga pushed the lead back up to 15 toward the middle of the half. The Bulldogs eventually opened up an 18-point lead with just over five minutes left in the game. It was their largest lead of the night.

USC showed some signs of life late, but the game was never close after that. The Trojans cleaned up their free-throw shooting in the second half, shooting nearly 78%. But USC’s shooting woes from beyond the arc proved to be critical. The Trojans shot only 27% from 3 for the game and allowed Gonzaga to shoot 54%. USC was also outgained on fast break points, scoring only eight in comparison to Gonzaga’s 21.

Through their first seven games this season, USC held opponents to 40% shooting from the field. Against Gonzaga, it allowed the Bulldogs to shoot 52%. Ellis had a team-high 28 points with seven rebounds and four assists. Collier led the team with six assists and contributed 14 points. No other Trojans scored in double digits.

The Trojans return to the Galen Center for a matchup against Long Beach State on Sunday, December 10 at 1 p.m.

Pitt too tall a task for USC women’s volleyball

The Trojans fell to the Pitt Panthers in the second round of the NCAA Tournament and will now prepare to change conferences without the help of Skylar Fields. (Photo by Wesley Chen)

By Thomas Johnson
December 02, 2023 at 8:51 pm PST

USC’s matchup against the Pittsburgh Panthers on the Panthers’ home court was emblematic of the last two seasons of women’s volleyball for the Trojans. They ride and they die on the back of senior outside hitter Skylar Fields. It was the latter for USC against Pitt, as the Trojans fell in four sets to the Panthers to end their season in the second round of the NCAA Tournament.

Despite a team-high 21 kills — no other Trojan had more than six — Fields also committed 10 attacking errors. USC was 1-3 this season when Fields had double-digit errors.

“I attack every game the exact same way,” Fields said in the postgame press conference. “I’m gonna give my all to my teammates. And it’s a team game, so I can’t do everything. And we fought, we battled and we’ve been doing that every single day.”

The Trojans seemed in control of the game through early parts of the match, as they took home a hotly contested first set 25-23. USC went on a 5-1 run to close out the opening action with help from two of Fields’ kills. Redshirt sophomore middle blocker Tyrah Ariail supplemented Fields’ play with four of her six kills coming in the first set.

“Clearly we can play at that level, we just have to sustain it,” head coach Brad Keller said. “I knew what we were going up against, we had a great game plan. They’re the No. 4 team in the country right now. There’s a reason, they’re good. And I thought we responded really well to the beginning of it, we just didn’t sustain it. But we can play toe-to-toe with anybody.”

Pitt started out the second frame on a 4-0 run of their own, but the Trojans were able to claw back and take a 16-12 lead, poised to take a two-set lead. But the Panthers showed why they are the No. 4 team in the country to earn a No. 1 seed in the NCAA Tournament.

Part of the reason Fields and the Trojans had so many attack errors was because of the height Pitt possesses on its roster, giving them the ability to contest and block USC attacks. The Trojans had 10 attack errors in the second set — seven of which came off of Pitt blocks — and the Panthers finished the set on a 13-4 run to take it 25-20. Three of Fields’ attack errors came during that Pitt run.

“[The Panthers] responded well and we just didn’t quite respond enough to get back and lost that rhythm,” Keller said. “It can happen like that, it can happen pretty quickly and it did and we were trying to figure it out and we just couldn’t.”

Pitt’s graduate middle blocker Emma Monks, with eight blocks across the four sets, and freshman opposite hitter Olivia Babcock, with six blocks, led the way for Panthers as they were able to show off their height against a shorter USC team. Five different Pitt players are listed at 6-foot-4 or taller, compared to just two such players for the Trojans.

USC just could not match up to Pitt’s height, as Monks and Babcock dominated the net for the Panthers.

“It’s really a puzzle,” Keller said. “When they start blocking you or they’re taking your lines, you’re gonna start hitting more across, you’re gonna tip out the setter. You’re just trying to create different scenarios.”

Despite fighting hard in the first two sets, USC could not keep it up in the final two as the Panthers won both 25-18. The third round of action was particularly devastating for the Trojans, as Pitt ran out to an 18-7 lead in the set, which was too much for USC to overcome.

The Trojans were able to close the gap to seven points by the end of the frame, but the 11-point deficit and Pitt’s .481 hitting percentage was just too much of a hole.

“A team like Pitt, when you get on runs, they’re not a team that you can just come back on,” sophomore libero Gala Trubint said. “They’re a good team, when they get on a run they’re gonna keep that run going unless they’re stopped ... I think we let off the gas a little in the third set and it might’ve cost us in that one.”

It was more of the same in the final set of the game, as Pitt took a 2-1 lead and never trailed again, although the Trojans did tie it up at multiple points.

The Trojans are likely losing Fields to graduation, but are still built for success in the coming years. 12 of USC’s 19-person roster are freshmen or sophomores eligibility wise, with three of them starting out on the court in the first set for USC. The Trojans also signed four high school prospects in their most recent recruiting class, further bolstering the team next year.

Now USC will try to improve on its success from this season, but in a new conference as the Trojans are moving over to the Big Ten in 2024.

RAMS: L.A. looks to extend win streak against Browns

By Adam Bradford
December 02, 2023 at 11:15 am PST

INGLEWOOD, Calif. — Coming off of back-to-back divisional victories, the Los Angeles Rams will look to stretch their winning streak to three games when they host the Cleveland Browns this Sunday at SoFi Stadium.

After upsetting the Seattle Seahawks at home in Week 11, the Rams rolled over the hapless Arizona Cardinals 37-14 last Sunday. Quarterback Matthew Stafford threw four touchdown passes, running back Kyren Williams racked up over 200 all-purpose yards and two touchdown receptions, and Los Angeles outrushed Arizona 228 yards to 73 in a wire-to-wire win.

The Rams’ 37 points scored was the team’s highest offensive output this season. Prior to Sunday, they had eclipsed the 20-point threshold just four times on the season, with the most recent instance coming all the way back on October 15.

On the other side of the ball, the Rams’ defense also enjoyed a strong day, led by two sacks from rookie defensive lineman Kobie Turner. After surrendering 43 points in an embarrassing blowout loss to the Dallas Cowboys last month, Los Angeles has now held its opponent to 20 points or fewer in three consecutive games.

On Sunday, they will look to continue that streak against a Browns team that has major uncertainty at the quarterback position. After losing starter Deshaun Watson for the season, Cleveland has rotated between journeyman PJ Walker and rookie Dorian Thompson-Robinson over the past two months. This week, they also signed longtime veteran Joe Flacco to give them an additional option at the position.

According to reports, it will be Flacco under center for Cleveland Sunday afternoon in Los Angeles. Flacco has not played since last season, when he appeared in five games with the New York Jets. The veteran quarterback is best known for his time with the Baltimore Ravens, whom he led to a Super Bowl victory in the 2012 season.

Kickoff between the Browns and the Rams Sunday is set for 1:25 PM PST on Fox.

USC football poaches UCLA’s D’Anton Lynn to be new defensive coordinator

Lynn helped guide the Bruins’ defense to a No. 1 rank in the Pac-12 in total defense this season.

UCLA defensive coordinator D'Anton Lynn talks with linebacker Choe Bryant-Strother (9) during a timeout during the second half of an NCAA college football game against Southern California in Los Angeles, Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. (AP Photo/Ashley Landis)

By Will Simonds December 01, 2023 at 8:05 pm PST

After two dismal defensive seasons under head coach Lincoln Riley, USC football has found a new defensive coordinator to replace Alex Grinch. Former UCLA defensive coordinator D’Anton Lynn will move across town to take the same role with the Trojans, Riley announced Friday. At just 34 years old, Lynn will manage a talented, but far too inconsistent USC defense as it transitions to the Big Ten for the 2024 season.

“We are thrilled to welcome D’Anton and his family to USC,” Riley said in a statement. “We simply couldn’t ask for a better addition to our staff. His successful experiences in both college and the NFL make him the perfect fit for our program.”

In his one season as the Bruins’ defensive coordinator in 2023, Lynn oversaw a defense that led the Pac-12 in yards allowed per game and ranked second in points allowed per game. In comparison, UCLA ranked No. 87 in the nation in total defense and No. 92 in scoring defense the year prior.

Lynn now will be tasked with completing a similar turnaround of a USC unit that has been one of the worst in the nation in recent years. Notably, when UCLA trounced USC 38-20 at the Coliseum last month, the Bruins allowed just three rushing yards from an explosive Trojan offense.

The Trojans’ former defensive coordinator Grinch was the recipient of frequent scrutiny across two seasons on Riley’s staff with USC, before being relieved of his duties on November 5 after a 52-42 loss to Washington.

Plenty of top defensive recruits in recent classes have come to play at the Coliseum, but the on-field product hasn’t lived up to expectations, especially compared to Riley’s high-octane offense on the other side of the ball. USC currently holds commitments from two defensive players listed in the top 100 of 247Sports’ recruiting rankings for the 2024 class: cornerback Marcelles Williams (No. 76) and edge rusher Kameryn Fountain (No. 85).

Before coming to Westwood, Lynn spent several seasons as an assistant coach in the NFL. He worked with the New York Jets, Buffalo Bills, Los Angeles Chargers, Houston Texans and Baltimore Ravens between 2014-22.

As a cornerback at Penn State from 2008-12, Lynn was selected as an All-Big Ten honorable mention three times, recording 162 tackles and four interceptions over four seasons. Lynn was signed as an undrafted free agent by the Jets in 2012, but he was cut during training camp. He is the son of Anthony Lynn, the former head coach of the Chargers and current assistant head coach of the San Francisco 49ers.

USC women’s volleyball sweeps UMBC in dominant NCAA tournament win

The Trojans took down the Retrievers in the program’s 34th first-round victory.

By nikki thomas December 01, 2023 at  6:47 pm PST

Despite losing four of its last five matches, USC women’s volleyball (19-12) advanced to the first round of the NCAA tournament to take on UMBC (17-8) on Friday. The Trojans (25-18, 25-10, 25-12) put together a resounding sweep over UMBC and are now 34-5 all-time in the NCAA first round. It was win or go home for USC, who has a No. 8 seed in the tournament.

The Trojans brought that mentality to the match and seemed to be in control from the very beginning. UMBC was aggressive early in the first set, taking a 7-6 lead over USC. The two offenses battled back and forth for a few possessions, but the Trojans started to get an edge behind kills from redshirt sophomore middle blocker Tyrah Ariail and senior outside hitter Skylar Fields. USC pulled away, executing a 4-0 scoring run to end the set and win 25-18. Both Fields and Ariail finished the period with four kills, with Ariail hitting 75.0% for the match.

“You have to come out firing in this tournament,” head coach Brad Keller said after the match. “We had a little bit of a slow start, but once we turned it on, I was really impressed and really happy with the level of focus and execution that these young women had today.”

Battle of the Beats: Spotify Wrapped vs. Apple Music Replay

USC students debate the best streaming service and its end-of-the-year rewinds.

A student dances at the “Light Up the Night” silent disco. Participants wore headphones that connected to one of two live DJ sets performed in the Village. (Photo by Tomoki Chien)

By ChristiAnne Ross and Yana Savitsky
December 01, 2023 at 4:54 pm PST

Apple Music’s Replay and Spotify’s Wrapped launched Tuesday and Wednesday, respectively — unveiling a year’s worth of listening history for their users worldwide. Whether students were labeled a “Vampire” by Spotify for listening to “emotional, atmospheric music more than most” or reached a new milestone on Apple Music, USC is divided over which platform is better.

“I think it’s a fun little thing people can bond over,” said sophomore psychology major Camila Beresford-Redman. “Although it’s fun, it doesn’t really mean anything.”

The format, originally ideated by Spotify in 2016, was later adopted by Apple Music in 2019, bridging the gap for all kinds of listeners. This year’s Spotify Wrapped featured new additions like “Sound Town,” a pixelated map that displayed a city with similar listening patterns to each user in addition to unique genre distinctions like Darksynth, Dream Plugg and Compositional Ambient.

According to the BBC, there are now over 6,000 genre distinctions on Spotify — which are used to sort each of the 100,000 new tracks uploaded every day. With 210 million premium users, Spotify still dominates the audio streaming subscription service charts compared to Apple Music’s 88 million global subscribers according to Music Business Worldwide.

Many USC students thought that Spotify was the clear winner, especially with its unique, colorful Wrapped format this year. Some even highlighted Apple Music’s downsides. “I don’t believe in paying for the service and the phone,” said junior Alani Smith, a film and television student. “[Spotify] caters to me.”

Others voiced their support for Apple Music. Freshman Ayana Gonzalez said, “Apple Music comes with my network carrier of choice, so I take advantage of that.”

Another new feature on Wrapped was the “Me in 2023′′ character, which “demonstrates a streaming habit that defined your music listening this year” according to Spotify. Options range from Alchemist to Time Traveler to Mastermind. Smith said her Wrapped character was a Cyclops. “They said I’m loyal... I stick to genres and artists like really long.”

One USC student even stood strong by YouTube Music, which only has 8.5 million subscribers — and no end-of-the-year recap, according to Music Business Worldwide. “I’m tired of the YouTube music slander. Yeah, it’s a little overpriced monthly, but I grew up literally listening to music off of the YouTube app because I didn’t want to pay for it,” said junior Faith Nguyen.

Nguyen also pointed out that you can listen to some edits on YouTube that are not accessible on other platforms. “Why go so close-minded as to use Spotify when you can literally access the world on YouTube?... I’m going to be a lone wolf about it, all right.”

Several students were hesitant to share their top artists on their Wrapped or Replay, believing that the platforms did not accurately represent their listening history this year. Beresford-Redman said Spotify “did me pretty dirty” this year in correlating the location of San Luis Obispo, California with her music habits. “It doesn’t tell me anything about my listening pattern.”

Gonzalez was hesitant to share her Replay as it features “some of the most mainstream on this planet” with Drake, A Boogie Wit da Hoodie and Beyoncé at the top. Smith, on the other hand, was embarrassed to admit that Kanye was her number two artist even though she stopped listening to him this year. But, Smith confesses she knows why Kanye made the cut. “Whenever I fly over to L.A., I keep Waves by Kanye on repeat and my flight is seven hours. But, I stopped doing that — like I did that for the flight,” she said.

While the music-listeners demographic is divided by the streaming platforms, the year-long wait to the next rewind of their music choices unites them.

USC Winter WonderLAnd activities to get you in the holiday spirit

Los Angeles and USC have a multitude of events dedicated to winter festivities.

Holiday string lights. (Photo courtesy of Dzenina Lukac)

By Reo and Ye Ji Jong
December 01, 2023 at 3:48 pm PST

It’s the most wonderful time of the year! Despite the lack of snow, Los Angeles is all for holiday cheer. For those spending your winter break in the City of Angels, here are our tree-topping experiences to keep your holidays bright.

What Trojans can do on campus for the holiday season:

Snow Fest
Both during and after finals, the university is hosting numerous festive events for students. The festivities start Friday when Residential Education and Student Life host Snow Fest between 5 p.m. and 8 p.m. The event is open to all USC Housing residents and will transform the Great Lawn into a winter wonderland, complete with activities, crafts and holiday snacks.

“Elf” (2003) Screening
Following Snow Fest, students can make their way to Tutor Campus Center’s Grand Ballroom for Late Night SC’s screening of “Elf” (2003). The Will Ferrell flick will open its doors at 8 p.m. and start around 8:30 p.m.

FreeSCycle Winter Clothing Drop ‘n’ Swap and Trojan Food Pantry
Until December 5, the USC Sustainability Hub in the Student Union will host multiple charity and recreational events. Both the FreeSCycle Winter Clothing Drop ‘n’ Swap and the Trojan Food Pantry Non-Perishable Food Drive will be held in the Sustainability Hub. Students will be able to pick up and/or drop off clothes from the Drop ‘n’ Swap.

DIY Arts and Crafts
On Monday, the “Hub for the Holidays” at the Sustainability Hub will host a DIY ornament and garland-making session from 3 p.m. to 4:30 p.m. on December 4. On the following day, students are invited to decorate cookies and watch horror film shorts at the same time. Coffee, hot cocoa and snacks will be provided on both days.

SC Winter Luncheon
To cap off the university’s holiday events, Student Life is hosting an SC Winter Luncheon on December 15 in the TCC Grand Ballroom. The event will run from 11:30 a.m. to 1:30 p.m. and RSVPs must be submitted by December 8 for admission. If you are not going home for the holidays, or if you live in Los Angeles, the luncheon would be a great way to end the semester.

Every corner of L.A. has a holiday tradition worth loving:

Marina del Rey Boat Parade
The Marina del Rey Boat Parade will flaunt the marina’s best-decorated holiday boats on December 9 at 5:55 p.m. The 60-year-old tradition is a staple of Marina del Rey and typically draws thousands to see the fireworks and thoroughly lit boats. The best viewing locations are Burton Chace Park and Fishermen’s Village. If you are willing to make a day trip out of it, the park is hosting booths, vendors and performances as late as 10 p.m.

Universal Studios
Los Angeles is home to Universal Studios Hollywood. The park prepared itself for the holiday season last month and will be continuing the festivities into early January. Universal Studios Hollywood is hosting two major holiday events this season: “Christmas in The Wizarding World of Harry Potter” and “Grinchmas.” Potterheads can catch shows in Hogsmeade and take in the beautifully decorated castle, while the nerds of the world can immerse themselves in Dr. Seuss’ “Who-tacular” Christmas creation.

Enchanted Forest of Light at Descanso Gardens
For a more down-to-earth experience, you might want to take a late-night walk through the Enchanted Forest of Light at Descanso Gardens. The La Cañada Flintridge location opens every day at 5:30 p.m. until January 7 and offers whimsical, Alice-in-Wonderland-esque environments for patrons to wander through. Tickets cost $45 for general admission.

The Grove
The Grove is an L.A. classic: it’s a bustling outdoor mall that’s filled with lights and decorations during the winter holidays. Open daily, it’s most popular once the sun sets for the holiday lights. “There’s a lot of little pop-ups [people] can go visit for the holidays, and it’s really beautiful. You should go check it out,” said Olivia Dean, a sophomore majoring in psychology.

Honorary mention: Disneyland
Although it’s not in L.A., Disneyland decked the halls with Christmas decorations. About an hour-long drive from USC, Disneyland is filled with fun holiday festivities. Visitors to the Anaheim park will see it lit up with festive lighting and may get the chance to catch Disney characters and other holiday figures in a parade. Tickets start at $96 for daily admission.

Although L.A. may not be known for its winters, visitors and residents will have plenty to do during the cold holidays!

South LA Social Media Fueling School Fights in South L.A.: Meaning Behind the Trend and How to Prevent It

Taking a closer look at the junction between school violence and social media

By Natalia Osuna December 01, 2023 at 3:47 pm PST

In South L.A., public middle and high schools have faced an epidemic of multiple fights occurring on a weekly basis. Students gather around to watch those fights and then holler, chant, and pull out their phones to record the fight. The footage is later posted on social media by students.

A recent study for the National Center for Education Statistics at IES titled Crime, Violence, Discipline, and Safety in U.S. Public Schools in 2019-20, analyzed this issue. The findings show that “60 percent of schools reported at least one physical attack or fight without a weapon at school. Nine percent of schools reported such an attack with a weapon.” Additionally, in schools where at least half of the students are from minority groups, “69 percent reported involving students in restorative practices. Rates were lower at schools with lower minority enrollment, ranging from 40 to 58 percent,” according to the same 2022 study.

“Violence is a form of survivalism to some groups. [In] some countries, they fight because there’s no other option. But when it comes down to young people, I think it really comes back to them not having the words, not having the alternatives. They don’t know how to be connected and how to have disagreements in a safe way,” said Holly Priebe-Sotelo, a professor at the USC Suzanne Dworak-Peck School of Social Work and an expert in school crisis response, adolescent bullying, abuse, and diversity and equity.

Priebe-Sotelo grew up in South L.A. and experienced violence in public schools herself, which pushed her brother to drop out of school. Due to this, she spent eighteen years in K-12 schools doing anti-bullying work by fostering connection between the students. Yet due to the violence and internalized trauma that she and her family experienced growing up in the South L.A. public school system, she decided to enroll her daughter in a private school so that she would have a better educational environment.

“From my experience in working in schools is that sometimes young people feel that there is no other option but violence. And so we have to teach young people alternatives to impulse,” Priebe-Sotelo said. “We need to teach them safe ways to act out aggressions or anger or disrespect.”

These fights are extremely harmful, yet the glorification and perpetuation of these on social media is where the deeper point of concern lies. In South L.A., where the majority of residents identify as either Black or Latinx, this violence is the product of other systemic issues.

“A lot of it comes back to internalized oppression. You know, a lot of kids have an internalized history of trauma where they don’t feel like their voice matters,” Priebe-Sotelo said. “And so it starts really kind of with those internal messages in our own minds that tells us this is all I’m good for.”

According to Priebe-Sotelo, the key to change is in learning and implementing new strategies that are more focused on empathy and human connection among students.

“We always encourage our school community to follow the District’s message: ‘If you see something, say something,’” a Los Angeles Unified spokesperson said. Additionally, students and parents can also use the LAUSD LASAR mobile app which allows those in the school community to anonymously report any issues such as fights, mental health incidents, or drug consumption.

“Los Angeles Unified takes the safety and well-being of our students very seriously. To support students, Los Angeles Unified offers schools several tiers of support, including––but not limited to––strategies to prevent, respond to, and recover from instances of student misconduct,” a Los Angeles Unified spokesperson said. “When examples of this occur, school staff who supervise students are expected to intervene appropriately, which includes notifying school administrators. They will investigate and take appropriate administrative action. The safety of students and staff is our top priority.”

Essentially, it all comes down to the system and values that teenagers are inheriting.

“The missing link here is to engage the parents,” Priebe-Sotelo said. “In private schools, parents must participate. There’s no question that they have to participate. So here in public schools, the parents and caregivers are almost nowhere to be found.”

Although social media plays a great role in perpetuating violence, it can be used as a tool to spread awareness and create change.

“Monitoring social media is a never-ending process where we’re, you know, we can’t police every single message that exists. It’s impossible. So therefore, we need to empower young people to do this and be responsible for their own behaviors,” Priebe-Sotelo said.

“Karen Bass — where are you?” Vendors at the Fiesta Mini Mall swap meet still fighting for their space

Residents of the South Park neighborhood are grappling with the looming permanent eviction, something many attribute to Mayor Karen Bass’ housing initiative.

At 8th and Spring, construction crews are laying the foundation for a 24 story tower that will contain 300 residential units.

By Veronica Garza and Kelsey Goldbach
December 01, 2023 at 3:45 pm PST

The Fiesta Mini Mall in South Los Angeles faced an eviction in late October, following pleas from the vendors for its closure to be postponed. No formal postponement of the building’s demolition has been announced. The marketplace was scheduled to be demolished to make way for an affordable housing project for low-income residents.

Vendors gathered at an L.A. City Council meeting on October 25 to communicate their struggles via public comment. They criticized Mayor Karen Bass’ absence from the meeting and asked for assistance in their relocation.

“We will not stop fighting because like I heard earlier, L.A. is for all, yet we only see how support is only given for the affluent people. I will not be able to pass down all the hard work my mother inculcated in me to my children,” vendor Maria Briseno said. “This not only affects one generation, but the others that follow.”

Briseno’s sister Esmeralda shared these sentiments. She said the council “fails to listen and help,” stating that many vendors have not yet found an affordable relocation site because “most swap meets around the area have been displaced.”

“We have been in contact with representatives of Karen Bass but they only listen and do nothing for us. Karen Bass — where are you?” Esmeralda said. “You have met with teachers, police officers and even small business owners. Do swap meet vendors not deserve the same level of respect?”

However, an Instagram post by @southcentraltenants and @latenants alluded to the Fiesta Mini Mall remaining in operation as of mid-November. The post depicts the Vendors Union of Fiesta Mini Mall gathering to demand that Mayor Bass and Councilmember Curren Price “find relocation for all vendors” or “step in to stop the demolition of the swap meet and secure a permanent stay.” The Fiesta Mini Mall Vendors’ Instagram account — @vendedoresunidos48thst — was tagged.

An Instagram user commented, “Is it still open [sic],” to which @southcentraltenants responded, “Yes and still going strong!” The commenter replied, “thank you went there yesterday and today :) [sic].”

Annenberg Media reached out to two vendors for additional comment, but received no response.

While the fate of the Fiesta Mini Mall swap meet is unknown, vendors and advocates alike continue to fight to keep their place in the South Park community.

Medical school fights on against misconceptions of South L.A.

Charles Drew University opens its doors and new possibilities for people of color in medicine

By Natalia Osuna December 01, 2023 at 3:41 pm PST

Robberies. Shootings. A lack of resources. For many, that’s what first comes to mind when they think of South L.A. Despite negative stereotypes, pockets of passion, vibrancy, gathering, and impact exist within the community. The Charles R. Drew University of Medicine and Science in Willowbrook is one of these. The university’s brand-new medical school opened its doors this past July with a historic first class of 60 students––mostly made up of people of color.

During the fall blocks, the program has provided students with a myriad of opportunities, resources, and even community service activities in the wider South L.A. that are pushing them to grow both professionally and personally. “There are a lot more Black and Brown individuals that would like to get into medicine than people may realize,” Aarin Huffman, a first-year medical student and member of the inaugural class, said.

According to a survey conducted by the American Association of Medical Colleges, 56% of active physicians identified as White, about 5.8% identified as Hispanic, and another 5% identified as Black or African American. This data demonstrates the lack of access into the medical field in specifically Black and Brown communities, which starts in high school or even earlier. Yet for residents of South L.A. who mostly make up those populations, having physicians who share similar identities can be transformative.

“Moving from high school to college, I think it was really just access to resources that would have helped to increase the minorities within health professions, such as the medical doctor track, that we didn’t have. I think it boils down to the resources,” Huffman said. Originally from Birmingham, AL, Huffman decided to become a doctor after seeing a lack of access to medical facilities and services in rural Lincoln, AL where she went to church. This, paired with her deep love for people, sparked a curiosity within her to ask herself how she could help.

“This program opens up a wide array or wide door for the community to heal. I’m not saying that it’s essentially broken down to the point of no return, but health care wise, it’s broken because of the access that is not there for it,” Huffman said. Providing all 60 students with access to basic resources, such as the school’s library, a laptop, a stethoscope, a blood pressure monitor, a white lab coat, and a diagnostic kit, the university strives to help mitigate any financial barriers they may have.

This ideology is based on Dr. Charles R. Drew’s values, an African-American physician who pioneered in blood preservation work. Following Drew’s impact, CDU’s mission emphasizes humanity and empathy before anything else. During Gateway, a six-week orientation, students were able to connect, get to know each other, and develop friendships with their peers as they transitioned into medical school.

“We talked about or we had lectures that were around social justice matters, which is a big mission and value of the school,” Huffman said. Then, classes kick off with a white coat ceremony. Instead of semesters, CDU’s curriculum is structured around blocks of five to six weeks. Gateway is the first block. Anatomy and physiology represent the second block, the next block is genetics and embryology, and lastly comes biochemistry. This gives students a well-rounded understanding of the material and preparation to work in the real world.

“What makes that better also is the faculty and staff. They make us feel like we’re winners. Like we can do this,” Huffman said. Dr. Margarita Loeza, the Assistant Dean of Admissions and Student Affairs at CDU, enjoys working with passionate students in the inaugural class. “We’re looking for students that are mission driven and mostly from the community and that want to serve the community of South L.A.,” Loeza said. “They seem happy and engaged and enthusiastic and they seem very proud to be part of the first class.”

CDU’s new medical school is just one of the many uplifting developments that are transforming the South L.A. area, bringing new hope and opportunities for growth. “It doesn’t just do it for LA County. It’s starting in LA County, but it’s starting a revolution. Not in a bad way. I like to use revolution, like John Lewis used to say, as good trouble,” Huffman said.

Tips for sustainable Trojans this holiday season

How to manage shopping, food and travel at this time of the year.

A polar bear made entirely of recycled trash is presented at the Grand Opening of the Sustainability Hub. (Photo by Drake Lee)

By Katherine Havens and Tobey Groome
December 01, 2023 at 3:35 pm PST

The holiday season brings plenty of cheer but December also brings an increase in shopping, food, travel; and subsequently a surge in waste. Although these things can be unavoidable, conscious efforts by individuals can help prevent an overwhelming amount of waste produced this holiday season.

Shopping, sales and gifts
According to the United States Census Bureau, e-commerce sales rose by 43% in 2020 due to the pandemic, and have been on the rise ever since. Added packaging trash and increased carbon emissions are direct consequences of shipping online purchases to the consumer. To prevent this unnecessary added waste, shopping in-person at stores is the more sustainable option. Online purchases are more likely to be returned than items bought in person, according to the National Environment Education Foundation. In addition to the added emissions from shipping products back, most returned items end up in landfills.

“More than 80% of returns end up in landfills or shipped to developing countries as garbage,” said Hitendra Chaturvedi, an Arizona State University Professor. By shopping in-person, the risk of added waste is drastically reduced.

Shopping second-hand is another way to ensure that your gift is as waste-free as possible. According to Goodwill’s website, thrifting causes less resource consumption, fewer things to be thrown away, and less chemical pollution. Consignment and thrift stores are widely available in L.A., and most cities in the U.S. Visiting one of these stores makes your gift more personalized and unique, as some recycled pieces can be unique and not found in stores that mass produce their items.

If you have time before heading home for the holidays, the USC Sustainability Hub is hosting a winter clothing drop ‘n’ swap and non-perishable food drive from now until December 5. Consider stopping by the Student Union building to donate lightly used winter clothing and/or add an item to your wardrobe. In addition, non-perishable food that is donated will be sent to the Trojan Food Pantry.

Food: holiday edition
Gifts aren’t the only environmentally unfriendly factor around the holidays, as food is another popular indulgence this season and a great perpetrator of waste. According to the Environmental Protection Agency, household waste increases by 25% around the holidays. The EPA has several tips on reducing food waste, including making a set grocery list to prevent overbuying, and storing leftovers in the freezer so they don’t go bad.

Finding new recipes to revamp your leftovers may encourage your family to eat the food from the day before and prevent the remnants of a large meal from being wasted. Upcycling food can become a creative way to both bring family and friends together as well as create a whole different and exciting meal. From sandwiches to soups to casseroles, the possibilities are endless.

“Cutting down on your food waste is a really important thing to think about during the holidays when we do tend to have these really big meals,” said Chelsea Graham, Experiential Learning Manager in the Office of Sustainability.

Leisure and travel
The holidays also give people a break, allowing travel to pick up a lot this time of year. Transportation is a top source of carbon dioxide emissions due to individuals returning home for the holidays, according to NEEF. To keep your carbon footprint low, itineraries must be carefully planned. When possible, use a bus or train to return to your family. In cases where this is not feasible, driving should be the next choice. Only if all other alternatives have been exhausted should you fly on a plane, as flying has the largest carbon footprint.

“If you can’t avoid taking that airplane, think about how you can reduce your carbon footprint once you get to your destination. So whether or not that’s once you get home, you’re doing more walking or taking public transit, doing more carpooling, all those things can really help, especially if you can’t avoid that big air travel,” added Graham.

Becoming aware of the increased potential for waste around the holidays is the first step to contributing your bit to the environment. Being as thoughtful as possible when buying gifts, food supplies and planning your travel is important to prevent an excess amount of trash and unused items from building up in your local dump.
